data.title: Mme. Rosay
data.meta_description: Talk story about watching French actress, Francoise Rosay, rehearse the part of Catherine the Great, in a play called "Once There Was A Russian", by Sam …
data.text:
The New Yorker, February 11, 1961 P. 25

Talk story about watching French actress, Francoise Rosay, rehearse the part of Catherine the Great, in a play called "Once There Was A Russian", by Sam Spewack, The rehearsal took place in a loft known as Schumer's warehouse on W. 53 St. Also in the cast: Walter Matthau, Albert Salmi, Julie Newmar, Carold Grace (Mrs. Matthau). Mme. Rosay is 69; has 3 sons and 2 grandsons. She said in Paris they do not rehearse in a place like this, but in the theatre they are to play in. This is her first time in a play in N.Y. She finds it interesting. Her husband was Jacques Feyder, who was a movie director; he died 13 years ago. She came to America for the first time in the 20's when her husband was invited to Hollywood to direct Greta Garbo in "The Kiss". All three of her sons work in the cinema: Marc Frederix, who is an art director; Paul Feyder, first assistant director, Bernard Farrel, assistant director and TV director as well.

Infiltrating the Far Right

The threat from domestic terrorism is rising, but, with Republicans decrying the “deep state,” the F.B.I. is cautious about investigating far-right groups. Vigilantes are leaping into the fray.

Trump’s Got Troubles

His campaign is careening, his poll numbers are slipping, and, after something of a summer lull, he is due for several confrontations in court.

Q. & A.

What the Latest Presidential Polls Say and What They Might Be Missing

Nate Cohn, the New York Times’ chief political analyst, breaks down Kamala Harris’s performance in the battleground states and how we should think about polling error.

On Television

The Kamala Show

How Vice-President Harris’s public persona has evolved, from tough prosecutor to frozen interviewee to joyful candidate.
